text: good morning everyone it's great to be
here like many of the honorees I'm
humbled to be in this this group and I'm
learning so much I'm learning so much
from the presentations I also want to
thank the CNE at C an en staff for
organizing all of these events for the
past couple days and of course for my
new moniker of waste wizard which is one
I haven't used yet but is rapidly
turning into my halloween costume thanks
to my students so and they say I have to
keep running with it so I'm gonna keep
running with it but I'm really here
today to talk to you about reimagining
wastewater and in my lab how we think
about the molecular design in both
materials and processes for resource
recovery which we define is making
making or extracting valuable products
from what most people consider waste so
hopefully by the end of this I have you
reconsidering waste in a new way and
that can be a little more profitable and
sustainable our story starts with three
main observations one wastewater is
plentiful wastewater is generated on the
order of 10 to the 15th liters every
year what this means to break this down
is we generate about three trillion
2-liter plastic bottles of waste water
every day and on a personal level
that's about 780 liters of wastewater a
day or 200 gallons and of course this
includes industrial wastewater but the
point is we're releasing tons literal
tons of wastewater into the environment
as we speak and so what we think about
is the fact that wastewater is plentiful
it's also heterogeneous most the time
when I say wastewater people think about
flushing the toilet and what happens
when you go to the wastewater treatment
plant as shown here but wastewater is
actually very heterogeneous it contains
different waters at different
compositions and for instance if we're
looking at grey water which is the water
that comes from everywhere in your house
or office building except your toilet
that contributes the majority of water
in domestic wastewater feces
unsurprisingly to most people
contributes the majority of the carbon
but urine which is something I've
studied in maybe more detail than anyone
wants to know about but I'll tell you
about it anyway because I'm on the stage
but urine has the majority of nutrients
in it nitrogen phosphorus and potassium
those same nutrients that we use and
fertilizers are coded for it even though
urines only one percent of wastewater
volume
lastly white wastewater is diverse we
think about municipal wastewater but
wastewater as a category includes things
like acid mine drainage and includes
things like agricultural waste water and
so just for a brief picture of expanding
this definition of wastewater these are
some of the other things we're talking
about when we talk about wastewater
whether that's from energy production or
from urban runoff storm water or
agricultural runoff like I mentioned
wastewater is kind of get a bad rap
because we think about them as
containing pollutants which absolutely
is true these pollutants like nitrogen
in some cases and phosphorus as well can
cause you to fication which is shown
here and this is simply the production
of algal blooms that can deplete aquatic
systems of oxygen and lead to cascading
effects in aquatic ecosystems one
example of this that's kind of
mind-boggling because this happens every
year in the Gulf of Mexico is that
there's a dead zone a hypoxic zone in
the Gulf of Mexico that happens from
nutrient runoff all along the Missouri
Mississippi River that's the size of New
Jersey every year and so this happens
every single year 5,000 square miles
there's a big zone of of low oxygen
levels that you can actually see from
space and so we of course acknowledge
the fact that waste water contains
pollutants but we also try to resituated
as an opportunity these pollutants in
one setting can be products in another
and by recovering them as products we
can incentivize the collection of waste
water and really think about closing the
loop so the one we've thought about most
in my research group is recovering
nitrogen as ammonium as fertilizer from
urine because that's where it's most
concentrated in domestic wastewater and
I wanted to give you a little broader
sense of the work that's going on in
this field in my research group and
beyond and things like recovering
phosphate and potassium which I've
already mentioned things like recovering
hydrogen fuel from different types of
wastewater and also making commodity
chemicals like hydrochloric acid and
sodium hydroxide from desalination brine
which is in some ways the waste of waste
waters and this has gained increasing
attention because we really have to
think about closing the loop right we're
no longer at a place where we have the
luxury of a linear economy in some ways
we have to think about making things
more circular and redefining waste if we
think about biology can teach us this in
some ways but for in biology waste is
really a concept right someone's waste
become someone else's input right and we
can think about making our industrial
ecology do this in the same way and this
is a report from the United Nations in
2017 that details some of the potential
of waste water like I said one of our
major philosophies in the group is it is
that extracting products from waste
waters can incentivize collection and
intensify treatment what I mean by
incentivize collection is the fact that
80 percent of wastewater that's
collected is discharged without
treatment right so a minority of
wastewater is even collected to begin
with but the vast majority of that 80
percent is discharged to the environment
without treatment so nitrogen again is a
case that we think a lot about and so in
most cases in industrialized settings
wastewater goes to our treatment plants
and we try to remove nitrogen from it to
avoid the eutrophication that I've
already talked about we do this with a
set of coupled biological processes that
have been well honed over the past few
decades nitrification denitrification
and these are very useful they convert
nitrogen as ammonium to nitrogen gas
which of course is innocuous to admit to
the atmosphere however when you expand
your system system boundary in your
control volume as which as chemical
engineers we think a lot about and if we
think about fertilizer production we
sort of do the reverse right with a
hammer Bosch process we take nitrogen
gas and reduce it to ammonium as
fertilizer and so what we think about is
if you look at this loop we're really
using two energy intensive processes
haber-bosch to produce fertilizer and
nitrification denitrification for
wastewater nitrogen removal and we're
using nitrogen gas as a very expensive
and energy intensive intermediate so our
question is let's close this loop short
cut it and recover nitrogen from waste
in its reduced form that it's already at
but now are now the challenges to make
it a selective separation and by
intensify treatment i mean reduced cost
energy inputs and reduce chemical inputs
as well and so we focus a lot on
selective separations because we have to
make high purity products right so in
the removal paradigm which is not bad
but is simply the way we've done things
and it served our purposes so far in the
removal paradigm we can do oxidation and
oxidation works too for pathogens it
works for trace organic contaminants it
works for dissolved organic matter and
it also works for nitrogen right we
oxidize nitrogen from ammonia to nitrate
and then we partially reduce it back to
nitrogen gas but if we're talking about
recovery we need to make high purity
products because we're talking about
plugging this in to an industrial supply
chain right we can't have if we want to
make a nitrogen fertilizer we can't have
a large amount of phosphate or a large
amount of organic matter so now now that
we're thinking about selective recovery
we need to think of a high purity and so
we do that by thinking about ammonia
disinfectants ammonia fertilizers is
shown here we want to recover those and
concentrate those but we need to exclude
other contaminants like trace organic
materials or antibiotic resistance genes
and so I'll tell you I'll give you a
brief overview of what we're doing in in
my lab in my research group and then
give you basically one slide on each of
these so first as we think about the
material side designing absorbance for
resource recovery second we think about
designing novel processes and our focus
is on electrochemistry as a platform
technology for the selective separations
third we think about contaminant fate so
extracting the good and leaving behind
or transforming what can threaten human
health or aquatic ecosystems and finally
we think about resource constrained
communities which Lisa mentioned and is
some of our work in these are pictures
from Kenya with the sanitation service
provider there so let's start with the
absorbent side of things so what we're
doing right now is synthesizing and
screening multifunctional adsorbents to
increase the selectivity for nitrogen as
ammonium we've recently gotten inspired
by some ammonium selective transporters
found on Animax bacteria and we've
looked at the amino acid sequences to
see what are the side chains that are
really conferring this ammonium
selectivity and so of course most ion
exchange resins for cations in
particular are made with negative
charges and so we've started this with a
sodium fumarate and sodium acrylate but
we've started looking at as well
kind of copying the side chains of the
amino acid you just saw in the last
crystal structure so for serene looking
at heme and a LMP and similar ideas for
phenylalanine histidine and here we're
using poly acrylamide simply because
they're cheap abundant and we can
customize them in different ratios and
so this is the synthesizing part and
then we screen these in large large
combinations and so what we're trying to
do here is take advantage of
the fact that ammonium is a really
unique cation right especially in
wastewater compared to things like
sodium potassium calcium magnesium
ammonium is one polyatomic and two it
can confer some hydrogen bonding that we
can really take advantage of and so this
is what we're going for with these
different monomers that confer hydrogen
bonding potentially with delocalization
cation PI bonding and of course the
standard ionic attraction on the process
side of things we've developed a new
process called electrochemical stripping
and the idea here is that we use
electrochemistry to selectively recover
nitrogen based on two properties its
charge and its volatility so this is our
electrochemical reactor with three
chambers an anode chamber a cathode
chamber and an acid trap chamber we feed
urine this was originally developed for
urine but we've since used it on other
high nitrogen content waste waters into
the anode and based on the
electrochemistry there's an external
circuit where electrons move and those
electrons are supplied by the oxygen
evolution reaction because there's an
there's negative charges moving
externally and through the circuit
there's an impetus for positive charges
to move as well and here's where we
select for nitrogen based on charge with
a cation exchange membrane once ammonium
is in the cathode the oxygen reduction
reaction occurs and so we've generated
hydroxide ions here and so we get an in
situ pH increase without having to add
any chemicals and so that transforms
ammonium into ammonia which as many of
us know is volatile and so that's where
we select for volatility so now we've
selected based on charge and volatility
ammonia gas is through is coming through
the membrane and rapidly hydrolyzes back
to ammonium and so what we've made here
is ammonium sulfate ammonium and sulfate
because we use sulfuric acid and
ammonium sulfate is a common liquid
fertilizer so again what we've done here
is concentrated ammonia based on charge
and volatility just because data is
important and you shouldn't just believe
what you hear here's the nitrogen mass
balance in terms of mass of nitrogen
versus time and just seeing that the
nitrogen leaves the anode comes into the
cathode as an intermediate but
ninety-three percent of it ends up in
the trap so this is indeed a good
recovery process and we do have
additional selectivity data to support
that we also looked at rate limiting
steps where
Mical engineers so that's a term we love
to think about and so we're thinking
about the fluxes through these two
membranes and which one is rate limiting
and how can we build a true operational
framework to better understand this
process that we developed at the concept
level on the contaminant side we're
thinking a lot about pharmaceuticals in
urine and in other waste waters in urine
in particular because urine contains 65
percent of the pharmaceuticals that we
excrete so this is of course something
we need to think about in particular the
effects of urine treatment processes on
pharmaceutical fate so this was some of
my my postdoc work at University of
Michigan with Krista Wigginton who's in
the audience and Nancy love and so we
took this screen of many different urine
treatment processes some new and some
old and what we did is we established a
concentration factor for it's kind of a
cost-benefit ratio here the
pharmaceutical is potentially damaging
to human health in the environment the
nutrient is the product that we want to
see and so we took this non-target
screening approach where each of these
lines here is a different peak found
through high resolution mass
spectrometry and we're looking at the
intensity fold change so effluent over
influent throughout a treatment train
and once we do this then we can start to
identify these different compounds like
naproxen or some other pharmaceuticals
and I'm giving a talk tomorrow more
about that another part of this
philosophy is that we want to work at
multiple scales and that's because
working at the lab scale is not enough
if we're trying to really change a
paradigm right we have to think about
the unit process scale and also the
systems level scale so at the molecular
level we think about molecular
mechanisms that the process we're
designing and evaluating these new
processes how well does it work
how can we optimize it at the system
scale we consider aspects like lifecycle
assessment to say what if everyone in
the city adopted this but we actually be
the effect on greenhouse gas emissions
so I'll walk you through the ion
exchange case just so you can see how
these investigations feed into each
other so at the molecular scale I
already introduced you to the new beads
we're making and these multifunctional
adsorbents that can demonstrate nitrogen
selectivity at the unit process level
what we do is actually put this in a
fixed bed which is how the treatment
would most likely occur and an
engineered process and we generate
breakthrough curves for example where we
can compare
the effluent concentration over time or
bed volume for different sorbents and
this is something we've done for
existing adsorbents already and then at
the system scale like I mentioned for
lifecycle assessment we can start to ask
really insightful questions like of the
whole new ion exchange process one how
does it compare to existing approaches
and - what's the biggest contributor to
energy and greenhouse gas emissions so
here we did this analysis for a San
Francisco kind of thought experiment and
most of us thought before doing this
that it would be transport right
transporting ion exchange cartridges
around the city but we were completely
wrong which is ok and taught us
something and it's really the acid that
we use originally the sulfuric acid we
use to regenerate the resin is actually
the biggest contributor and so this
drove us back into the lab to think
about alternative regeneration schemes
but the key part is this as an insight
that we wouldn't find if we if we waited
until the technology was mature so to
speak to then optimize it so on the last
part of what we do we think a lot about
resource constrained communities and
this is how I got first interested in
this work was thinking about limited
access to sanitation for billions of
people around the world and so we've
taken our ion-exchange techniques and
we've applied them with a partner in
Kenya and we've shown that the value
here was that urine direct fertilizers
were locally sourced because most
fertilizers have to be imported into
Kenya and so this graph is just showing
the cost per kilogram nitrogen and you
can see our ion exchange process is 70
to 80% cheaper to produce than
fertilizers than importing fertilizers
into Kenya we also looked at repeat
performance over time and scaling up our
process tenfold from one toilet scale to
10 10 to 10 toilets and this is
something we've begun to spin out in a
startup company called electro sand that
partners with sanitation service
providers around the sub-saharan Africa
region and just to wrap up here we
really believe that these what we're
doing at the molecular level can really
impact these really big wicked problems
as we call them in the development
engineering space and so in terms of the
sustainable development goals of course
we tie into the clean water and
sanitation but also the circular economy
and thinking about environmental
protection as well and so we approached
scarcity from many angles right water
scarcity
energy scarcity food and fertilizer
scarcity and of course sanitation
scarcity as well and so this also ties
into really big questions like can we
make pollution extinct right these are
the big things we're talking about and
in some ways that's a new idea but in
other ways this is an excerpt from the
Clean Water Act in 1970
that was the goal originally we've sort
of gotten misguided and incremental but
the goal was really to eliminate waste
completely and and we also think about
big questions like how can we maximize
the residence time how many times a
molecule goes through our circular
economy as we're designing of these 21st
century scarcity mature and scarcity
resilient economies and finally just on
a more personal note to me when I teach
an introduction the chemical engineering
class and some of the feedback I've
gotten is their favorite lecture despite
my love for mass balances and
stoichiometry is really when we talk
about the big challenges students are
entering our universities thinking about
how do we solve the big challenges that
I hear about every day right climate
chains water scarcity energy scarcity
and I see our work on resource recovery
as a way to connect those really big
problems all the way down to the
molecular scale and say here's the work
I do and here's the impact it can have
and so we've done this through a variety
of videos that have been released also I
shamelessly use the fact that urine is
intriguing to people to get them to ask
questions to get them to think about our
work so this video in particular is
called something like how your pee could
feed billions of people not my title but
it gets people talking about it right
and also through some of our business
competitions as well and I really see
this as a way to open the door to get
more people from all backgrounds
involved in chemistry because these are
global challenges that we all have to
have to navigate so with that I'll
acknowledge my wonderful research group
and some funders and I'm happy to
continue the conversation later thank
you
[Applause]
